item.title: Wrath of Achilles
item.description:
Wrath of Achilles

The first line strikes like a war trumpet: “Sing, goddess, the anger of Achilles son of Peleus, that brought countless ills upon the Achaeans.” I remember rereading it aloud one evening, the ancient words pressing themselves onto my tongue like incantations. This anger—mēnin—is no petty grievance but something elemental, corrosive, and divine. From the outset, Homer does not present war as glorious or redemptive, but as a theatre of rage and loss, governed by capricious gods and fragile men.

item.title: A Man of Many Turns
item.description:
Man of Many Turns

I have always preferred nostos to kleos. The Iliad dazzles, yes, but the Odyssey lingers. It is quieter, more cunning, and in many ways, sadder. If the Iliad concerns what it means to die well, then the Odyssey is concerned with how one might live afterward.

“Tell me, Muse, of the man of many turns, who wandered far after he had sacked the sacred city of Troy.” Odysseus is not praised for his strength, but for his polytropos—his turning mind, his adaptability, his duplicity. He is a man perpetually becoming, never quite at rest. His journey home becomes a labyrinth not of distance but of identity.
